content.description: Nice route just left of Bloomin' Union. Start in the left facing dihedral a 5' left of the Bloomin' Union finger crack start. When you get past the blocky start move left and up the thin dihdral. There are plenty of nice face holds to supplement the tiny corner. Gear is good but small and spaced. Join the the top of Bloomin' Union for the last 15', shares anchor.
content.protection: Single rack 00-#4 should be fine. Maybe doubles of C3s.

content.description: Located left of inz and outz. Go up fractured finger splitter left of tree. Negotiate the cool triangular roof and pull into slab micro splitter with thin pro.  Then short off fingers section where the rock steepens to a rest in the corner. Then bust left up a super steep head wall with a left diagonal crack feature. It's been all gear to this point now clip 2 bolts up steep face holds. Chain anchor.
content.protection: 2 each from 000 to .4 cam.  1 orange metolius 3 .5s 2 .75s and a 1.  Several long runners.  A couple of small wires.

content.description: This is one of my favorite, all natural gear pitches of climbing anywhere.  Easily toproped after climbing the Sword.  A short bit of steep hands leads to finger crack which takes you under the roof.  Plug in a black alien in a seam to the right, then bust out some wild moves out left, and undercling back right again to turn the roof.  One more crux section guards the chains.
content.protection: Nuts, doubles to #2 Camalot with triples black-yellow Alien.
content.location: Starts just left of the Sword, under the big roof 70 ft up.

content.description: The only offwidth in the main part of the waterfall.  A striking #4-#5 crack in a left-facing corner
content.protection: Double set of cams from 0.4 to #5 c4.

content.description: Shares a start with Dirty Deed, but traverses left to awesome off-fingers splitter
content.protection: Double set of cams to 2", 2 Bolt anchor

content.description: Turkish Tickling climbs the splitter tips and fingers crack left of Spite and Malice.  The initial broken finger-crack and flare of Spite and Malice leads directly to the Turkish Tickling Crack.  Stay in the fingercrack and continue up to the Spite and Malice anchors, rejoining that line for only the last 5 feet or so.
content.protection: Lots of small cams.  Triples (or more) from 0 C3 to .4 c4 with a few larger pieces up to #1 C4
content.location: Splitter fingers and tips left of Spite and Malice

content.description: Starts right of the mini-tombstone.  Climb loose steep start to better climbing above.
content.protection: Double set to #2 C4.  Bolted Anchor

content.description: To the left of Flashflood, and shares anchor. Climb broken face to gain tips/finger crack in left facing dihedral. Continue up the excellent crack to top.
content.protection: double if not triples to #2 camalot, 1 #3.
content.location: 25ft R of the spring.

climbs.name: Terminator
climbs.fa: FA Jason keith, FFA John Mattson

content.description: Terminator is perhaps the all natural gear, test piece crack at the Waterfall: Really cool climbing that will challenge all parts of your game. Begin as for Guacamole, but once through the chossy roof band (arrange gear carefully here to prevent rope drag) traverse left on a series of awesome buckets to the crack. You can't miss it. Solid jams to a stance, then full-on liebacking through a bone-crunching tips section to a final boulder problem. Hasta la vista, baby.
content.protection: Triple set to 1".

content.description: Interesting start to get established in the splitter.  I reached out to put the first piece in the finishing splitter from a wide stem.  I really loved the way the crack on the right opened up from medium nut to #1 camalot, very striking.
content.protection: nuts, double up small tcus to #2 camalot
content.location: Just as you arrive at the base of the Waterfall, turn left and look for the striking twin crack 30' off the deck.  Anchor is bolted and we found carabiners, although they are a bit worn.

climbs.name: Suzie and Ishmael Do the Nasty
climbs.fa: TR: D Singer, Equip and FFA: Unema/Crawley 2013

content.description: This striking arete was originally toproped by Darren Singer from the anchors of Flash Flood.  It was equipped and led as a mixed climb in 2013.  The current line shares the start with Thick and Thin, traversing right under the hanging arete to gain the first of 6 bolts.  From here the line continues up the arete, moving slightly left to share just a few moves with Thick and Thin after the 4th bolt.  The climb finishes up the blank prow with two bolts.  Beautiful, difficult, and committing arete climbing on bullet stone with great friction.
content.protection: Gear is required to protect the first 30 feet or so that are shared with thick and thin.  An assortment of cams from 0.5" to hand size (with long runners) protects this section well.  Once you gain the arete, the route is protected by 6 bolts.  No more gear required.
content.location: Start on Thick and Thin and move right, staying between Thick and Thin and Flash Flood

content.description: An infamous, in your face Waterfall pitch, Spite and Malice has everything a route needs to be a classic. A heads up start on suspect rock demands a certain nimbleness and leads you to a wide, obtuse stem box. Work your way up the left finger crack, (which turns into Turkish Tickling) until you can traverse into the right hand finger crack (5.10). Keep moving up this crack as it grows ever steeper! Look for face hold relief, but be ready to jam your heart out. A sustained pitch that delivers a full body workout.
content.protection:
Doubles to #.5, then triples of #.75, #1, #2 Camalots. Three or four runners.

 70M rope
content.location: Middle left wall.

content.description: Slaughterfall climbs the blunt face and prow right of flash flood.  Start as Flash flood, moving right after about 25 feet to clip the first of a few bolts.  Continue up the face onto a nice slab.  from the top of the slab, gaze up at the improbable face above and summon your creativity, balance, and tenacity for the run to the chains.  Beautiful moves on immaculate stone with awesome new-school waterfall features.
content.protection: This route shares a start with Flash flood, so take the same gear as for the start of flash flood.  After that start, the route is protected by a few bolts with great gear between.  Bring a single set from 000 to .75 camalot, plus some nuts.  The section above the slab protects well with a small nut, a red and a blue lowe ball.  Finish on a two-bolt anchor.
content.location: Starts with FlashFlood and moves right.  Independent anchor.

content.description: On the far left hand side of the Left Wall, this pitch climbs a chunky right facing dihedral with double cracks up high. Climb blocky rock to wavering hands and finger crack. After the crux up high, instead of moving left into gnarly left facing dihedral, move right onto the face and follow thin crack, and good horizontal holds to the anchor of Ninja Warrior.
content.protection: Doubles to 2" TCU and Camalot, Large/medium/small wires.  Runners.  Chain anchor with fixed biners.
content.location: On the far left hand side of the LEFT Wall, locate two distinct right facing dihedrals and a prominent and clean arete in between them.  Rising Sun is the blocky dihedral on the left.

climbs.name: Righteous Pump
climbs.fa: J. Keith on original K. Kent on direct start/finish

content.description:
A straightened out and much improved version of Righteous Dump. The old line was so wandering it really detracted from what is otherwise a nice route. It started on Fister, traversed under MATH, went up the nice dihedral, and then at the big roof traversed even further right to the Giardia anchor.  

  In 2015, I added 2 bolt direct start, put an anchor 15' above the roof capping the nice dihedral, and cleaned some loose blocks off the line.  

  Start just left of Giardia Crack, 2 bolts (5.10+) and then a run out but very easy romp (5.7) to the base of the obvious right facing dihedral. The dihedral is standard fun 5.10 Waterfallness. When you get to the roof instead of bailing out right as for the original line, buck up and claw your way up and over(5.11+). The gear is excellent to the roof and then there's a bomber small cam placement immediately above it, after which you make an exciting run for the anchor with nothing but air below your feet.
content.protection: Double or triple rack of small stuff to #.75 C4. Singles of #1-3 C4.   Save a small piece or 2 for the roof. A couple draws/slings also.

content.description: climb awkward flare below Fister but turn roof to the right, diagonal up to thin cracks to big roof then head right to Giardia anchors.
content.protection: doubles
content.location: left of Giardia Crack, right of Fister

content.description:
Pyr·rhic Vic·to·ry  

noun \ˈpir-ik\ˈvik-t(ə-)rē\:   A victory with such a devastating cost that it is tantamount to defeat. 

  Start in the same spot as Vertebrae but move up the bolted face. Follow the bolts to a shallow dihedral, and up to the splitter roof crack, resisting the urge to move right onto Vertebrae. After pulling the middle of the roof continue up overhanging ground to the chains. 

  Taller people will probably find the bottom crux much easier than I did because their height should obviate dynoing. 

  Protection in the middle dihedral is mostly small and can be tricky to place, so beware.  

  I should also mention that while cleaning this route I wailed on the seemingly detached roof blocks (including the Vertabrae roof) with a 3' wrecking bar and they are completely solid.
content.protection:
3 bolts. Lot of slings, double rack from 000 C3 to .3 C4 with maybe a third .3 size piece, one #2 C4, and tiny to medium nuts and a ball nut or 2 should be adequate. There is a placement a bit a above the third bolt that is the only gear in that area which takes a blue/yellow metolius offset cam much better than any non-offset cam.

 I would advise putting a full length sling on every piece to avoid the rope running sharply over the edge of the roof.

 Please leave the fixed biners on the chains

content.description: Phlegm of Fury starts to the right of Guacamole. Climb up blocks to short layback, then up and over small bulge.  Work your way up the large flake system on the right side of the stembox.  Once you are standing on top of the large flake, move left to gain the finger crack and sharp tips.  Several desperate locks will get you past the crux, and keep trending right.  There is another little crux up high that should get your attention again if you let it wander.  After this crux, continue up the corner, placing gear in the crack and in bomber horizontal gas pockets.  As the rock becomes more pocketed, the character of the climb changes, relying more on horizontal edges and pockets than only the crack.
content.protection: Triple set of TCU #0- #4, single set up to #2 Camalot, small/ medium wires, runners. Save some tips and fingers pieces for the top. Chain anchor- fixed biners.
content.location: Middle of the left wall, right of the Terminator and Guacamole.

climbs.name: Outrageous
climbs.fa: R. Warren, D. Singer, D. Miller

content.description: Outrageous is to the left of Morticia, in a very shallow and shady mini amphitheater. Climb up steep, broken rock with marginal gear towards a chunky looking roof. The beginning can be a bit unnerving because of the trust factor involved in several large flakes for both pulling on and gear... Once the main crack has been gained, you will enjoy perfect gear and excellent climbing passing jugs every body length or so. A long, enjoyable pitch if you can make it past the start.
content.protection: At least a double set starting at 0 TCU- #1 camalot, bulking up on the finger and thin hands sizes.  Small/medium wires.
content.location: Way left on the Left Wall, past Terminator and Giardia.  Left of Morticia.

content.description: Orphan blood cocktail starts on a face with finger crack just left of the Dagmar/ SBBSBD start and heads straight up to a wide, blunt prow. Technical compression and crimping continue for five bolts. The blunt prow leads into a steep featured dihedral.
content.protection: Quickdraws, double cams from 00 to 0.4 C4 and a set of small nuts
content.location: Between Phlegm of Fury and Dagmar.  Start just right of the tree

climbs.name: Original Sin
climbs.fa: TR. D. Singer  FFA  Matt Swartz

content.description: if you like heady arete climbs this is it. standard 25ft of waterfall climbing to the arete proper. bouldery start with deadpionts, slaps, gas pockets, credit card crimping and layback smears. if you get on this route and wonder why there are 2 bolts and a perfectly good crack 3ft to the right, its because to do the arete as an arete at no point can you reach over and place gear. expect delicate, reachy and balancy moves. all the gear is in good horizontals . i wouldnt say its runout but if you peel off  its gonna be big, but safe
content.protection: single set .2- #1, 2 draws, slings FIXED BINERS on anchors
content.location: way down on the left between Rising Sun and Ninja Warrior. the right side of the arete

content.description: Seldom Climbed 5.10 to the left of The Tyrant
content.protection: Double Set to 3"

content.description: Ninja Warrior is the dihedral to the right of Rising Sun and a significant step up in difficulty and quality. Start up blocky rock and climb towards the finger crack dihedral passing a couple ledges. Once in the dihedral expect tight fingers with big moves in between good locks. The upper section is sustained for the grade, and may feel more like 5.11a during an onsight.
content.protection: Triples on #00- #2 TCU's single set of other cams.  Small/medium wires.  Runners.  Chain anchor fixed biners.
content.location: Far left hand side of the LEFT wall.  Very stand out finger crack in right facing dihedral.

content.description: This route shares the start of Giardia Crack, but busts right just below the roof into the dihedral immediately right.  Arrange pro carefully when moving right and then up through the roof -- the rock is pretty broken and loose here.  Up higher the pro improves through a fingers crux.  Continue up face holds and easier climbing up and slightly right (avoiding the temptation to step left to Giardia Crack) to a bolted anchor.
content.protection: SR.  70m cord nice for getting down.

content.description: start up a funky chimney with some awkward jams. grab a sharp blockette and pull through a slot to a no hands ledge. use long slings down low or you can pull your rope through to reduce drag. get some pieces up high before you take off. theres a slab on the right and an arete on the left. some cool stemming gets you up to a rest. .2/RPs. then the crux , i wont tell you much but use your feet and push really hard. the gear is tiny and its all pretty good. its only 5.11, but you'll need to sack up for this all natural gear line, think mayflower direct but harder.
content.protection: heavy on the fingers on down to thin, RPs and one thin hand piece for the start.
content.location: between vertebrea and midwestern gangster

content.description: Interesting climbing over thin gear on a white face left of Uncle Fister
content.protection: Nuts and nuts and some small cams

content.description: Start on Uncle Fister, traverse right to chunky flare, rejoining Fister at the top
content.protection: Double set to 4"

content.description: A new cleaner version of an old chossy rte called nitrogenous waste,
content.protection: std waterfall rack with xtra small tcu's, chain anchor
content.location: left of most excellent, at the sword area

content.description: Typical far-left 5.10.  Loose start to really nice crack on grippy rock.
content.protection: Double Set to #3 C4 with extra .4 to .75 C4

content.description:
An arete?  A dihedral? Both?  This smashed in arete combines beautiful movement on a striking feature with bullet basalt.   

  Begin as for Follow your Doubt and climb up to the first bolt.  Continue through the bolts and finish up, pl;acing a few pieces
content.protection: Bolts, plus a single set of gear from 0 c3 to 0.75 camalot with extra fingers.
content.location: Begin with Follow your Doubt and move right into the smashed-in arete.

content.description: The first 100% bolted route at the waterfall.  The first three moves off the deck are likely the crux of the route.  Move up the dihedral onto the steep face.  This leads into fantastic sports pulling on brilliant rock.  Continue up the arete.  The tenth bolt is on the left side of the arete.
content.protection: 10 bolts to chains.
content.location: Start in the wide scoophedral left of midwestern gangter.

content.description: Insomnia is a heady lead, with steep, thin, and runout climbing on the menu. Start as you would for the Terminator, but at the top of the pillar, move left over blocky terrain towards the roof. Expect hard climbing for a bit, but it backs off towards the top.
content.protection: Doubles from #00 to #2BD, a single #3BD. Small and medium sized wires.
content.location: To the left of Terminator, and to the right of Spite and Malice.

content.description: This is the same route as What are You On? but instead of finishing left on the 5.12 headwall splitter go right ten feet to the Midwestern Gangster anchors.
content.protection: Small wires, a tiny cam and gear to #1 Camalot. Chain anchors.
content.location: Variation to What Are You On?

content.description: Guacamole shares a start with the hard splitter "Terminator" (which is just left of "The Sword") and just right of Spite and Malice.  Climb up junky rock to a hand crack that thins.  Stemming crux up high is over quickly.  Kind of awkward movement on this climb.
content.protection: SR.

content.description:
Giardia Crack is a superb, all natural gear line and a classic medium for Waterfall sports action. The crux involves some powerful moves over the roofy bulge on positive holds. This is one of my favorite pitches on the Left Wall. Always exciting and savory.

 This route starts above the obvious little spring that trickles out at the base of the wall, which also explains the name. From the nineties into Y2K climber’s would maintain a small pool to keep thier crag beers somewhat cool, however, while accomplishing the first goal, the residual spring water on the beer cans has made more than a few climber’s sick.

Climb a slightly unpleasant off fist size crack to the roof which has a very thin crack splitting it. Plug in a couple pieces of gear, and get ready to crank out some awesome moves which seem puzzling until you start into it. Continue up the dihedral into a fantastic hands section. After that the crack begins to tighten down again into another little .10+/.11- section which guards the anchors.

Multiple people have ripped their crux gear #.5. Make sure you have some gear in before the roof. See comments below.
content.protection: Standard
content.location: Left side above the natural water spring.

content.description: Start up some hollow flakes making your way up to a small roof.  Negotiate the roof with good stems and finger locks.  Get established in the final stem box with twin tips cracks.
content.protection: #1 Met. up to .75.  Triple .4   Two bolt anchor
content.location: Past Vertebrae, just to the left of Earth Diver.  Look for the white stem box up high.

content.description: Follow your doubt up the twin thin cracks, stemming between and staying left when things get a bit too wide to bridge.  Technical and engaging climbing over good gear leads to the imposing roof.  Pull the roof and establish on the headwall  to reach the anchors!
content.protection: Gear, and only gear.  Bring a double set from 000 to #2 camalot, extra green and red c3 size, a single #3 as well as a full complement of nuts.  Protect mostly the left crack, then the roof, then clip the biners on the 2-bolt anchor!
content.location: This route is the obvious twin-crack stembox capped by a roof right of Earth Diver and left of White Bread World.

content.description: Flashflood is one of the better warm ups on the Left Wall and features hands through fingers jamming with excellent face relief. The pitch is pretty solid, and good gear can be found throughout this all natural gear route.
content.protection: double tcu's, single set the rest.
content.location: To the right of Thick and Thin. Also shares an anchor with T and T.

content.description: Begin route by climbing first 35 ft of dagmar. Move right onto arete. Power through numerous compression arete moves to a rest.  After the rest launch into the namesake moves. Try to rip that arete off and send
content.protection: A single set cams up to #2    6 bolts
content.location: Arete right of dagmar.

content.description: Make some technical and interesting moves through blocky but solid rock to gain a sweeping low-angle fingers and tips crack.  The feet are slick and the crack is sharp, but the rock is excellent.
content.protection: Double set of cams from #0 C3 to 0.5 C4, probably a single set of .75 to #2 C4, nuts
content.location: Starts a few feet right of fool's progress.

content.description: Another Far Left 5.10.  Rarely climbed.   From Bloom's Sedona Rocks: Start in flared corner... pull roof on right.
content.protection: Double Set to 3"

content.description: A quality bolted direct start to the Tyrant. 3 bolts of steep pocketed face climbing at 11d. Continue past the 5th class middle section and finish on the 11+ splitter that is the Tyrant.
content.protection: 3 Bolts then gear for the Tyrant. Bring a finger piece to get to the first bolt.

content.description:
Start as for Smoke Big Doobs, but quickly hang a left and wade through a little funk to gain the nice looking dihedral. 

  Crux is fingers in a corner, which gradually eases up until the crack peters out. Float up and left through gas pocketed face climbing. Stoppers, small gear, and some patience will serve you well on your way to the anchors.
content.protection: Stoppers and cams up to maybe a #.75 or #1 BD. Might want to beef up on the tiny through fingers.
content.location: Shares start with SBDSBB. The dihedral proper lies left that route and right of Phlegm of Fury.

content.description: Another nice pumpy crack climb.  Your experience on this climb will depend on the length of your legs and the size of your hands.  (Big hands and short legs would be a bad combination.)
content.protection: Coubles to #3 Camalot, with 3 #0.75's and 3 #1s.
content.location: Hard to describe without a picture.  Starts under a small roof about 30' right of the pinnacle.

content.description: Certified Freak is the left of the two tempting smashed-in aretes.  A quality Waterfall-style mixed route, bring your quickdraws and microcams.  Begin on moderate and fun climbing left of Follow Your Doubt and make your way up to the first bolt.    Rest up and launch into the thin and interesting crux sequence, clipping bolts and placing a couple small pieces.  Above the crux, things remain interesting as the route follows unique and good rock to a two-bolt anchor.
content.protection: Quickdraws and a double set of cams from 000 c3 to 0.5 c4 with a single set from 0.75 to #3 c4.  Bring a few small nuts/RP's.  A red slider or two can be placed, but there is other gear as well.
content.location: Just left of Follow Your Doubt.

content.description: A good hard pitch to the left of Turkish Tickling and Spite and Malice. Start out on loose, though moderate climbing for twenty feet or so and then move left towards a small roof and dihedral. Climb the dihedral to the top. Thin at the top.
content.protection: Extra small stuff. 70m rope
content.location: To the left of Spite and Malice, middle of the wall.

content.description: Butter up and get ready to place some nuts on this gorgeous dihedral.  It's defining feature is the cute tree growing out at around the 60 foot mark.  Begin on moderate terrain slightly right of the corner and reach the base of the clean dihedral.  Fun and thoughtful stemming and edging leads to a beautiful tips to fingers crack.  Make your way around the tree and finish left on the anchors of Earth Diver
content.protection: Double set of cams from 00 BD to #1 camalot   Nuts, lots.   Butter
content.location: Butternuts lies right of Earth Diver and left of Follow your Doubt.

content.description:
The Bus Stop to Nowhere starts in the dihedral just right of the start of Guacamole and Terminator.  Climb up the dihedral and pull around to the right, climbing interesting ground to gain the thin seams on the face right of Guacamole.  Continue up the seams through thin jams and sidepulls to gain a splitter finger crack in a corner. 

  Dave Bloom and I made the first known ascent of this line.  A two bolt anchor had been placed by another party, but the line was completely un-cleaned.
content.protection:
RP's or small nuts essential, Single set of cams from 000 C3 to #2 C4 with doubles from 0C3 to 0.5 C4.  A red or yellow slider is helpful. 

  Upon a few more ascents or attempts, consider bringing double set of sliders from blue to yellow with double rp's. 

  Protection is thin, sparse, and tricky.

content.description: A powerful,technical,and thin steep corner, with good but intricate protection. Very engaging the whole way.
content.protection: 000-0.5 camalot, offset nuts, extra 0's (purple   Metolius or equivalent)
content.location: Start right of Outrageous and left of Morticia, in a fractured finger crack with edges. Climb the thin steep corners above the ledge, and finish on a devious headwall. Chain Anchors.

content.description: To the right of the Sword you will notice two bolts; one jacked, one “good”. The route starts up the face and arete. Turn the corner and look for a thin crack splitting the face. A good wire (#5 BD?) here and some harder moves take you to some jugs and a steep thin crack to the anchors. A very good pitch if you can figure out where to climb. Resist the temptation to stray too far right.  Bolted anchor at the true top.
content.protection: Small through medium wires, TCUs
content.location: Right of the Sword.

climbs.name: A White Bread World
climbs.fa: John Crawley, D. Bloom, J Unema

content.description: Begin with fun and moderate climbing on blocky and solid rock.  Continue up to bolts on a clean face and dihedral on white rock.  Crimp, stem, high-step, and finesse your way through the low crux on the beautiful white rock, then catch a shake for the pumpy upper section.  Launch into steep and featured rock, pulling roofs and steep faces on sinker pockets.  Beautiful climbing and awesome movement.
content.protection: Single set of cams plus quickdraws for 7-8 bolts.
content.location: 25-30ft. To the right of earth diver.

content.description:
The Left Wall is a stunning section of rock which sports heady starts that lead to wonderfully split cracks.  It is the meat and potatoes of the Waterfall area.  Many of the routes here were done by Darren Singer, Daniel Miller, and Jason Keith in the early nineties. Many of these pitches are regarded as classic. Includes all routes from Rising Sun on the left to Bladerunner on the right. 

  The Left Wall includes the historical sub areas Left End, Tombstone Area, Pinnacle Area, and the Sword Area, laid out in more detail in the Bloom/Wolfe Sedona Guide. 

  This wall gets morning sun, and afternoon shade.  But, be careful because the base is overgrown and often shady...
